etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in Thomas Wilson (d. 1581), humanist and administrator. From post-classical Latin Eutopia (T. More 1516: see note) from ancient Greek εὐ- + τόπος place + -ία, punningly after post-classical Latin Utopia utopia

definitions: A perfect (imagined or hypothetical) society or state of existence; a place of supreme happiness. Also: a literary work describing such a place; a vision of an ideal state of existence.
